title: Tesla Cybertruck
content:
{{Short description|Electric pickup truck developed by Tesla, Inc.}} {{About|the Tesla pickup|Tesla's semi-trailer tractor-unit truck|Tesla Semi}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2019}} {{Use American English|date=November 2019}} {{Infobox automobile | sp = us | name = Tesla Cybertruck | aka = | image = Cybertrucklogo.svg | alt = Cybertruck logo | upright = 1.1 | caption = [[File:Tesla Cybertruck outside unveil modified by Smnt.jpg|frameless|upright=1.25]]
The Cybertruck at its unveiling event | manufacturer = [[Tesla, Inc.]] | production = Mid-2023 (to commence){{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u5w_VkAx6tc&t=1346s | title=Elon Musk Unfiltered: Interview Part 3 (Bonus Material) | website=[[YouTube]] }} | assembly = [[Giga Texas]] | class = {{Unbulleted list |[[Light commercial vehicle]]/[[M-segment|Multi-purpose vehicle]] (EU) |[[Full-size pickup|Large pickup]] (North America) |[[Amphibious vehicle]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.carscoops.com/2022/10/elon-musk-says-propeller-or-creative-wheel-hub-design-can-transform-tesla-cybertruck-into-boat/|title=Elon Musk Explains How Propeller And "Creative Wheel Hub Design" Can Transform Tesla Cybertruck Into Boat |first=Brad |last=Anderson |work=Carscoops |location=US |date=2022-10-11 |access-date=2022-11-20}} }} | body_style = 4-door polygonal [[pickup truck]]{{cite news |url=https://www.topspeed.com/cars/car-news/the-tesla-cybertruck-s-polygonal-design-may-be-weird-but-it-s-not-the-first-ev-with-this-shape-ar187130.html |title=The Tesla Cybertruck's polygonal design may be weird, but it's not the first EV with this shape |first=Ciprian |last=Florea |work=TopSpeed |location=US |date=25 November 2019 |access-date=26 November 2019}} | platform = {{Unbulleted list |Tesla in-house }} | motor = Internal Permanent Magnet - Synchronous Reluctance Motor (IPM-SynRM) | related = | designer = {{unbulleted list |[[Franz von Holzhausen]] |Sahm Jafari{{cite web|url=https://www.autoevolution.com/news/tesla-model-zero-envisioned-by-cyberpunk-pickup-truck-designer-sahm-jafari-138629.html|title=Tesla Model Zero Envisioned By Cyberpunk Pickup Truck Designer Sahm Jafari|date=2019-10-29|first=Mircea|last=Panait|work=Auto Evolution|access-date=30 October 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191030041229/https://www.autoevolution.com/news/tesla-model-zero-envisioned-by-cyberpunk-pickup-truck-designer-sahm-jafari-138629.html|archive-date=30 October 2019|url-status=live}} |Ian Kettle{{cite web|url=https://www.artstation.com/artwork/1nDN5X|title=Cybertruck|date=2019-11-23|first=Aybars|last=Turan|work=ArtStation Folio|access-date=28 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191128065647/https://www.artstation.com/artwork/1nDN5X|archive-date=28 November 2019|url-status=live}} |WooTak Kim |Julien Bilodeau }} | layout = {{unbulleted list | [[Rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|Rear motor, rear-wheel drive]] | [[All-wheel drive|Dual- or tri-motor, all-wheel drive]] | Quad-motors, [[Individual wheel drive]]{{cite web |date=2022-05-21 |title=Tesla Cybertruck Will Have Quad-Motor Option, Rear Steering |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-quad-motor-rear-steering/ |access-date=2022-05-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220521030751/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-quad-motor-rear-steering/ |archive-date=21 May 2022 }} }} | predecessor = | length = {{convert|231.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cars.com/articles/tesla-cybertruck-impressive-specs-killer-price-polarizing-looks-413819/|title=Tesla Cybertruck: Impressive Specs, Killer Price, Polarizing Looks|date=2019-11-22|first=Brian|last=Normile|work=Cars.com|access-date=24 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191223003355/https://www.cars.com/articles/tesla-cybertruck-impressive-specs-killer-price-polarizing-looks-413819/|archive-date=23 December 2019|url-status=live}} | wheelbase = {{convert|149.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-rivian-r1t-compared-data-specs/|title=Tesla Cybertruck vs. 2021 Rivian R1T: How the Electric Pickups Compare|work=[[Motor Trend]]|last=Yekikian|first=Nick|date=2019-11-22|access-date=2019-11-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122114656/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-rivian-r1t-compared-data-specs|archive-date=22 November 2019|url-status=live}} | width = {{convert|79.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|75|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | chassis = Stainless steel exoskeleton }} The '''Tesla Cybertruck''' is an upcoming [[Battery electric vehicle|battery electric]] [[light duty truck|light-duty truck]] announced by [[Tesla, Inc.]] in 2019. Three models have been announced, with [[Electric car EPA fuel economy|EPA range]] estimates of {{convert|400-800|km|mi|round=10|abbr=out|lk=|sp=us}} and an estimated {{Convert|0-100|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} time of 2.9–6.5 seconds, depending on the model. The stated goal of Tesla in developing the Cybertruck is to provide a [[sustainable energy]] substitute for the roughly 6,500 fossil-fuel-powered trucks sold per day in the United States.{{cite tweet|number=331796308631367681|date=2013-05-07|access-date=2019-11-20|first=Elon|last=Musk|user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|title=Tesla priority is electrification of cars, so priority is Model S, Model X, then mass market third gen vehicle & truck}}{{cite interview|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/11/2/18053424/elon-musk-tesla-spacex-boring-company-self-driving-cars-saudi-twitter-kara-swisher-decode-podcast|first=Elon|last=Musk|subject-link=Elon Musk|title=Elon Musk: The Recode interview|interviewer=[[Kara Swisher]]|date=2018-11-05|work=[[Recode]]|via=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|quote=personally most excited about the pickup truck. ... futuristic-like cyberpunk, "[[Blade Runner (franchise)|Blade Runner]]" pickup truck. ... don't know if a lot of people will buy this pickup truck or not, but I don't care. ... We wanna get gasoline, diesel pickup trucks off the road. ... it's the thing that I am personally most fired up about|access-date=16 September 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190912031821/https://www.vox.com/2018/11/2/18053424/elon-musk-tesla-spacex-boring-company-self-driving-cars-saudi-twitter-kara-swisher-decode-podcast|archive-date=12 September 2019|url-status=live}} The base price of the [[rear-wheel drive]] (RWD) model of the vehicle was announced to be [[United States dollar|US$]]39,900, with [[all-wheel drive]] (AWD) models starting at US$49,900.{{cite interview|first=Elon|last=Musk|subject-link=Elon Musk|interviewer=Ryan McCaffrey|date=2019-05-29|location=Tesla Headquarters, [[Palo Alto, California]]|title=Episode 200: My Elon Musk Interview|series=Ride the Lightning|url=https://teslapodcast.libsyn.com/episode-200-my-elon-musk-interview|format=offset 51:02|quote=we don't want it to be really expensive, ... it's got to start at less than $50,000 dollars, it's got to be like $49,000 dollars starting price, {{abbr|max|maximum}} ... ideally less ... it has got to be something that is affordable ... you've got to be able to get a really great truck for $49,000, or less, ... it's going to have incredible functionality, from a load-carrying standpoint, look amazing, ... but it won't look like a normal truck ... it's going to look pretty [[science fiction|sci-fi]], ... not going to be for everyone, if somebody just wants to have a truck that looks like trucks have looked for the last twenty years, thirty or forty years, then this truck probably isn't for them, going to be a truck that is more capable than other trucks ... it'll be a better truck than an equivalent ... better truck than an [[Ford F-150|F-150]] in terms of truck-like functionality, be better sports car than a standard [[Porsche 911|911]] ... [the teaser image] is the front ... like a Bladerunner truck|access-date=14 October 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191013150842/https://teslapodcast.libsyn.com/episode-200-my-elon-musk-interview|archive-date=13 October 2019|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/21/tesla-cybertruck-unveiled.html|title=Tesla unveils its first electric pickup, the Cybertruck, starting at $39,900|work=CNBC|date=2019-11-21|access-date=2019-11-22|first=Lora|last=Kolodny|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122043542/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/21/tesla-cybertruck-unveiled.html|archive-date=22 November 2019|url-status=live}} Production of the dual-motor AWD and tri-motor AWD Cybertruck was slated to begin in late 2021, with the RWD model release date in late 2022, but it was pushed back multiple times.{{cite web|title=Tesla quietly delays Cybertruck to 2022|url=https://www.engadget.com/tesla-cybertruck-delay-2022-150309858.html|access-date=2021-08-08|website=Engadget|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|last=Jin|first=Hyunjoo|date=2022-01-14|title=Exclusive: Tesla delays initial production of Cybertruck to early 2023 - source|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/exclusive-tesla-delays-initial-production-cybertruck-early-2023-source-2022-01-13/|access-date=2022-01-15}} {{As of|2022|July}}, the start of production is estimated to be in mid 2023. == History == In 2012{{cite tweet|number=230487450882019328 |first=Elon|last=Musk |user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|date=2012-08-01|access-date=2019-11-21|title=Would love to make a Tesla supertruck with crazy torque, dynamic air suspension and corners like its on rails.}} and 2013 Elon Musk discussed the desire to build a truck with load-compensating suspension, making comparisons with a [[Ford F-250]].{{cite conference|title=2013 Teslive Event|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8n-xsEjq7pk&t=32m |date=2013-07-13|publisher=Tesla|conference=Teslive 2013|location=[[San Jose, California]] |quote=I am quite keen on building a truck ... [[air suspension]] that dynamically adjusts the load and keeps the angle of the truck correct ... was driving an [[Ford F-250|F-250]] down [[Interstate 405 (California)|the 405]] ... it was resonating|via=YouTube}}{{cite tweet|number=338117807910813696 |first=Elon|last=Musk|author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|date=2013-05-25|title=Would love to do a pickup truck. Something {{abbr|w|with}} ultra low {{abbr|cg|centre of gravity}} for sports car handling, dynamic air suspension & mega torque.}} In early 2014 Musk predicted 4–5 years before work could start on the product.{{cite interview|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xvH825IWPM0&t=2m8s |first=Elon|last=Musk |subject-link=Elon Musk|interviewer=[[Poppy Harlow]]|department=CNN Money|work=CNN|date=2014-01-16 |title=When will you be able to afford a Tesla?|via=Youtube|type=video offset: 2:08|quote=Yeah, we'd like to produce an electric pickup truck; we're not really thinking much about that, but that is part of our long-term plans. Would imagine that is probably something like 4‒5 years.}} In mid-2016, Musk outlined the intent for a new kind of consumer pickup truck,{{cite web|publisher=Tesla, Inc.|url=https://www.tesla.com/blog/master-plan-part-deux?redirect=no|title=Master Plan, Part Deux|first=Elon|last=Musk|date=2016-07-20|access-date=2019-11-16|quote=With the [[Tesla Model 3|Model 3]], a [[Tesla Model Y|future compact SUV]] and a new kind of pickup truck, we plan to address most of the consumer market.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191116060648/https://www.tesla.com/blog/master-plan-part-deux%3Fredirect%3Dno|archive-date=16 November 2019|url-status=live}} and suggested using the same [[chassis]] for a van and a pickup truck.{{cite tweet|number=759798110470205440 |first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|date=2016-07-31 |title=probably makes sense to build off the pickup truck chassis}} In late 2017, the size was estimated to be at least that of a [[Ford F-150]], in order to be large enough to enable a "game-changing" feature.{{cite tweet|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|date=2017-12-26 |number=945729229001334784 |title=Similar total size. Maybe slightly bigger to account for a really gamechanging (I think) feature I'd like to add.}} During the [[Tesla Semi]] and [[Tesla Roadster (2020)|Tesla Roadster]] unveiling in November 2017, a picture of a "pickup truck that can carry a pickup truck" was displayed.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5RRmepp7i5g&t=9m30s |title=Tesla Semi & Roadster Unveil|via=Youtube|first=Elon|last=Musk |publisher=[[Tesla, Inc.]]|quote=For interests sake we created a pickup truck version of the [[Tesla Semi]]. It's a pickup truck that can carry a pickup truck. By the way, you can legally drive that—it shouldn't be legal, but...—you'll be able to legally drive that with a normal driver's license. It's kind of wrong, but I like it.}} Background ideas had been in preparation for nearly five years.{{cite tweet|number=945713737729634304 |user=elonmusk|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|date=2017-12-26|access-date=2019-11-20 |title=I promise that we will make a pickup truck right after Model Y. Have had the core design/engineering elements in my mind for almost 5 years. Am dying to build it.}} In late 2018, Musk anticipated a prototype to be ready to show in 2019.{{cite tweet|number=1072488765753618437 |user=elonmusk|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|date=2018-12-11|access-date=2019-11-20 |title=I'm dying to make a pickup truck so bad ... we might have a prototype to unveil next year}} In March 2019, following the [[Tesla Model Y]] launch, [[Elon Musk]] distributed a [[teaser campaign|teaser image]] of a vehicle described as having a [[cyberpunk]] or ''[[Blade Runner (franchise)|Blade Runner]]'' style,{{cite news|url=https://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-blade-runner-everything-we-know-about-elon-musks-6-seater-pickup-truck-2771401|title=Tesla Blade Runner: Everything We Know About Elon Musk's 6-Seater Pickup Truck|first=Jerome|last=Santos|date=4 March 2019|access-date=19 March 2019|work=[[International Business Times]]|quote=pickup truck ... dual motor all-wheel drive, ... outlet for up to 240-volts normally used for heavy-duty tools and can tow up to 300,000 pounds. ... Tesla pickup truck will look like a proper truck, a design barely seen in electric vehicles so far. ... will have a "cyberpunk, [[Blade Runner (franchise)|Blade Runner]]-like" look, ... a futuristic design.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306160850/https://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-blade-runner-everything-we-know-about-elon-musks-6-seater-pickup-truck-2771401|archive-date=6 March 2019|url-status=live}} with the form resembling a futuristic [[armoured personnel carrier|armored personnel carrier]].{{cite tweet|number=1183583315263131648 |user=elonmusk|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|date=2019-10-14|title=Cybertruck doesn't look like anything I've seen bouncing around the Internet. It's closer to an armored personnel carrier from the future.}}{{cite interview|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|access-date=2019-11-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lS3nIyetS4I&t=10m47s |interviewer=John F. Thompson|date=2019-11-05|location=San Francisco|work=Space Pitch Day|title=Elon Musk's Complete interview at Air Force Space Pitch Day|quote=We're going to come out with the Tesla pickup truck which we call the Cybertruck. I mean, it looks like an [[Armoured Personnel Carrier]] from the future. Yeah, it won't look like a normal truck and people might not like it. I like it! It's going to look like it came from a movie set when it goes down the road; ...what is that thing? It's literally [[bullet proof]]. ... If I can elaborate on that: a lot of times people try to make products that they think others would love, but they don't love them, themselves; if you don't love the product, you should not expect that others will. ... Know your own heart, and if it's compelling to you, it will be compelling to others.}}{{cite tweet|number=1102345986117033984 |first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|date=2019-03-04|access-date=2019-11-20 |title=Yes. Personally, I'm most excited by the Tesla Truck. Maybe it will be too futuristic for most people, but I love it.}} It was rumored to be named the ''Model B''.{{cite web |url= https://insideevs.com/news/363685/tesla-pickup-truck-model-b/ |title= Tesla Electric Pickup Truck To Be Called Model B? |author= Eric Loveday |date= 6 August 2019 |publisher= Inside EVs |access-date= 1 December 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191130030729/https://insideevs.com/news/363685/tesla-pickup-truck-model-b/ |archive-date= 30 November 2019 |url-status= live }}{{cite news |url= http://ibtimes.com/tesla-model-b-release-it-elon-musks-pickup-2819920 |title= Tesla Model B Release: Is It Elon Musk's Pickup? |date= 29 August 2019 |author= Lorraine Lorenz |newspaper= International Business Times |access-date= 1 December 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191206222112/https://www.ibtimes.com/tesla-model-b-release-it-elon-musks-pickup-2819920 |archive-date= 6 December 2019 |url-status= live }}{{cite magazine |url= https://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/hybrid-electric/a29787807/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-truck-what-we-know/ |title= Everything We Know About Tesla's Mysterious New Pickup Truck |author= Eric Adams |date= 21 November 2019 |magazine= Popular Mechanics |access-date= 1 December 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191126025544/https://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/hybrid-electric/a29787807/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-truck-what-we-know/ |archive-date= 26 November 2019 |url-status= live }} On November 6, 2019, Tesla filed for a trademark on "Cybrtrk", which was granted under [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] 88682748; it was abandoned on August 10, 2020.{{cite web |url= https://trademark.trademarkia.com/cybrtrk-88682748.html |title= Cybrtrk Trademark Information |id= USPTO 88682748 |date= 6 November 2019 |publisher= Trademarkia |access-date= 6 December 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191206132926/https://trademark.trademarkia.com/cybrtrk-88682748.html |archive-date= 6 December 2019 |url-status= live }} In mid-2019, the towing capacity of the vehicle was stated to meet or exceed that of a [[Ford F-150]].{{cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2019/06/11/tesla-annual-shareholders-meeting-2019/|title=Elon Musk talks up Tesla's 'Cyberpunk truck,' and 400-mile range EVs|first=Richard|last=Lawler|date=2019-11-06|access-date=2019-07-28|work=[[Engadget]]|quote=The "Cyberpunk truck" ... being designed to "meet or exceed an [[Ford F-150|F-150]] ‒ if the F-150 can do it then a Tesla Truck should be able to do it." ... that if "you're driving it down the road, it will look like it came out of a sci-fi movie" and called it "the coolest car I've ever seen."|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190711174744/https://www.engadget.com/2019/06/11/tesla-annual-shareholders-meeting-2019/|archive-date=11 July 2019|url-status=live}} In June 2019, Musk noted that an [[amphibious vehicle]] design concept—based partly on [[Wet Nellie]], the submarine car from the film ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]''—was possible.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Va5i42D13cI&t=52m26s|title=Tesla Annual Shareholders Meeting|date=2019-06-11|first=Elon|last=Musk|quote=[Musk] a car that can go in the water basically? [Questioner] On, or under, or both, the water? [Musk] It's funny you should mention that ... if you make it a big bigger then you can actually have a [[submarine]] car. It's like technically possible. I think the market for this will be small; small but enthusiastic. So... we do actually have a design for a submarine car.}}{{cite tweet|number=1197638937109336066|user=elonmusk|first=Elon|last=Musk|author-link=Elon Musk|date=2019-11-21 |title=Cybertruck design influenced partly by The Spy Who Loved Me|link=no}} Musk had bought a Wet Nellie used in the filming at a 2013 [[Sotheby's]] auction.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/22/james-bond-lotus-sports-car-elon-musk-bought-inspired-tesla-cybertruck.html|title=This is the James Bond sports car Elon Musk bought for nearly $1 million that inspired Tesla Cybertruck|last=Huddleston|first=Tom|date=2019-11-22|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2019-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191127225950/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/22/james-bond-lotus-sports-car-elon-musk-bought-inspired-tesla-cybertruck.html|archive-date=27 November 2019|url-status=live}} In response to queries for an unveiling date,{{cite tweet|user=elonmusk|number=1102343438668713986 |date=2019-03-04|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|access-date=2019-10-15|title=No, that [Tesla Truck] unveil is later this year [2019]}} Musk stated in late July 2019, "We're close, but the magic is in the final details. Maybe 2 to 3 months", indicating late 2019.{{cite tweet|date=2019-07-27|first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|number=1155184195586519040 |title=We're close, but the magic is in the final details. Maybe 2 to 3 months.}} The unveiling was then scheduled for 21 November 2019 at the Tesla Design Studio, next to [[SpaceX]] headquarters in Los Angeles—the same month, year and location that the movie ''Blade Runner'' was set in.{{cite tweet|number=1181990398379483137 |first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|title=No change|date=2019-10-09}}{{cite tweet|number=1192117194756243457 |first=Elon|last=Musk |user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|date=2019-11-06|access-date=2019-11-06 |title=The date is strangely familiar ...|link=no|location=Los Angeles}}{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-fu7jN2_2pE |title=Blade Runner – Opening Titles |via=YouTube |access-date=6 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191106171138/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-fu7jN2_2pE |archive-date=6 November 2019 |url-status=live }}{{cite tweet|number=1192113294036754432 |first=Elon|last=Musk |user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|date=2019-11-06|access-date=2019-11-06 |title=Cybertruck unveil on Nov 21 in {{abbr|LA|Los Angeles}} near SpaceX rocket factory}}{{cite tweet|number=1170401244310949888 |first=Elon|last=Musk |author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|title=[We're almost there] ... November [2019] most likely|date=2019-09-07}} The truck was launched under a graffiti-themed logo of "Cybertruck", and a new trademark request was filed with the graffiti logo at the same time.{{cite magazine |url= https://www.wired.com/story/cybertruck-swag-floods-amazon-etsy/ |title= Cybertruck Swag Has Flooded Amazon and Etsy |author= Louise Matsakis |date= 26 November 2019 |magazine= Wired |access-date= 6 December 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191130081124/https://www.wired.com/story/cybertruck-swag-floods-amazon-etsy/ |archive-date= 30 November 2019 |url-status= live }} In April 2022 Elon Musk joined the new prototype of the Cybertruck onstage at the Cyber Rodeo Event in Texas, where he revealed a new detail, no door handles. Musk said that the truck can sense your approach and "just knows that it needs to open the doors."{{cite web |last=Goodwin |first=Antuan |title=Updated Cybertruck, Futuristic Robotaxi Teased at Tesla's Texas Cyber Rodeo |url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-cyber-rodeo-giga-texas-recap-cybertruck-robo-taxi/ |access-date=2022-04-09 |website=Roadshow |language=en}} Additionally Tesla has reportedly decided to allow the rear glass of the truck to drop, which would optimize the Cybertruck’s capability to carry cargo.{{cite web |last=Merano |first=Maria |date=April 7, 2022 |title=Tesla Cybertruck functions & improvements teased at Giga Texas Cyber Rodeo |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-improvements-cyber-rodeo-teaser/}} === Unveiling === {{multiple image|perrow = 1|total_width=240 | image1 = 20191121-tesla-cybertruck-window-steel-ball-before.jpg | image2 = Tesla Cybertruck damaged window.jpg | image3 = 20191121-tesla-cybertruck-shattered-windows-url.jpg | footer = Window damage caused by [[Franz von Holzhausen]] during unveiling event }} Cybertruck was unveiled at the Tesla Design Studio in Los Angeles on 21 November 2019. During the unveiling, Tesla claimed that the Cybertruck's "Armor Glass" windows were virtually unbreakable, but two windows shattered when [[Franz von Holzhausen]] threw a metal ball at each of them.{{cite web|last=Mak|first=Aaron|date=2019-11-22|title=Here Is What Will and Won't Break Tesla's New Cybertruck|url=https://slate.com/technology/2019/11/the-windows-on-teslas-cybertruck-are-not-unbreakable.html|access-date=2020-05-13|website=Slate Magazine|language=en}} Musk jokingly exclaimed that "the ball didn't make it through" and "we'll fix it in post".{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/21/20975475/tesla-cybertruck-announcement-musk-electric-truck-pickup-features-range-price-release-date|title=Elon Musk just announced the new Tesla Cybertruck|last=O'Kane|first=Sean|date=2019-11-21|website=The Verge|language=en|access-date=2019-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191126153855/https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/21/20975475/tesla-cybertruck-announcement-musk-electric-truck-pickup-features-range-price-release-date|archive-date=26 November 2019|url-status=live}} He later claimed that the windows were damaged because, in an earlier demonstration, the door was hit by a sledgehammer and that cracked the base of the glass.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/25/20981489/tesla-cybertruck-glass-window-fail-elon-musk-explanation|title=Elon Musk explains why Tesla's Cybertruck windows smashed during presentation|work=[[The Verge]]|last=Vincent|first=James|date=25 November 2019|access-date=25 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191125123816/https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/25/20981489/tesla-cybertruck-glass-window-fail-elon-musk-explanation|archive-date=25 November 2019|url-status=live}} At the end of the presentation, the Tesla Cyberquad, an [[all-terrain vehicle]] (ATV), was driven onto the bed of the Cybertruck using built-in ramps in the tailgate. The Cyberquad was plugged into the Cybertruck's onboard power outlet to charge the Cyberquad's batteries. The ATV will be available for sale as an optional package with the Cybertruck.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/21/20977300/tesla-atv-electric-features-range-price-release-date-announcement-elon-musk-all-terrain|title=Tesla made an ATV to complement its futuristic Cybertruck|date=21 November 2019|access-date=5 December 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191125075008/https://www.theverge.com/2019/11/21/20977300/tesla-atv-electric-features-range-price-release-date-announcement-elon-musk-all-terrain|archive-date=25 November 2019|url-status=live}} Many social media commentators disliked the sharp contours and unusual exterior.{{cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/11/22/tech/cybertruck-tesla-pickup-truck-jokes/index.html |title=Tesla's Cybertruck has become the butt of every internet joke |first=Matt |last=McFarland |work=CNN |location=US |date=22 November 2019 |access-date=27 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122235642/https://edition.cnn.com/2019/11/22/tech/cybertruck-tesla-pickup-truck-jokes/index.html |archive-date=22 November 2019 |url-status=live }} Tesla, Inc. stock declined 6% following the announcement.{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/11/22/tesla-tsla-stock-down-electric-pickup-unveiling-market-missing-point/|title=Tesla (TSLA) stock down after electric pickup unveiling — market is missing the point|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=2019-11-22|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=2019-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122170238/https://electrek.co/2019/11/22/tesla-tsla-stock-down-electric-pickup-unveiling-market-missing-point/|archive-date=22 November 2019|url-status=live}} On 23 November 2019, Musk tweeted that Tesla had received 146,000 pre-orders in the first 1.5 days after the unveiling—each requiring a {{USD|100}} refundable deposit—with 42% choosing the dual-motor configuration, 41% choosing the tri-motor configuration, and 17% choosing the single-motor configuration.{{cite web |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-vault-bed-cover-in-action-video/ |title=Watching Tesla Cybertruck's 'vault' bed cover in action is hypnotizing |first=Simon |last=Alvarez |work=Teslarati |location=US |date=24 November 2019 |access-date=27 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191124220133/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-vault-bed-cover-in-action-video/ |archive-date=24 November 2019 |url-status=live }}{{cite tweet|author-link=Elon Musk|number=1198344195317985280|title=146k Cybertruck orders so far, with 42% choosing dual, 41% tri & 17% single motor|last=Musk|first=Elon|date=2019-11-23|user=elonmusk|language=en|access-date=2019-11-23}} The number was reported to be 250,000 on 26 November.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1199526897887195136|title=250k|last=Musk|first=Elon|date=2019-11-26|website=@elonmusk|access-date=2019-11-27}} Tesla released a video of Cybertruck pulling a rear-wheel-drive [[Ford F-150]] uphill in a tug of war.{{cite tweet|number=1198751258384818176|title=Cybertruck pulls F-150 uphill|last=Musk|first=Elon|date=2019-11-24|user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|link=no|language=en|access-date=2019-11-26}} Various news outlets pointed out this was simply due to the Cybertruck's heavier weight.{{Cite magazine|title=Tesla Cybertruck vs. Ford F-150: It's All About the Friction|language=en-us|magazine=Wired|url=https://www.wired.com/story/tesla-cybertruck-vs-a-ford-f-150-its-all-about-friction/|access-date=2020-12-16|issn=1059-1028}}{{cite web|title=Here's the math behind Tesla's dumb Cybertruck vs F-150 tow test|url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2019/12/02/heres-the-math-behind-telsas-dumb-cybertruck-vs-f-150-tow-test/|access-date=2020-12-16|website=TechCrunch|language=en-US}} In January 2020, ''[[Automobile Magazine]]'' named Cybertruck the "Concept Car of the Year" for 2019.{{cite news |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-concept-car-of-the-year-award |author=Joey Klender |title=Tesla Cybertruck wins Concept Car of the Year award for its insanely unique design |work=Teslarati |date=6 January 2020 |access-date=7 January 2020}} == Features == The proposed truck uses [[self-leveling suspension]] which compensates for variable load and some models feature [[all-wheel drive]]. The company states that other standard features will include on-board [[power inverter]]s for supplying both 120 and 240-volt electricity, allowing use of power tools without a [[portable generator]]. An [[air compressor]] for powering [[pneumatic tool]]s is included. The exterior stainless steel sheet-metal is said to be [[Bulletproofing|bullet-resistant]]. All vehicles are also planned to come with [[Tesla Autopilot]], and they are planned to have the hardware capabilities for fully autonomous operation.{{cite news |url=https://www.foxnews.com/auto/tesla-cybertruck-pickup-revealed |title=Tesla Cybertruck pickup revealed with bulletproof body and $39,900 starting price |first=Gary |last=Gastelu |work=Fox News |location=US |date=2019-11-22 |access-date=2019-11-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191125173343/https://www.foxnews.com/auto/tesla-cybertruck-pickup-revealed |archive-date=25 November 2019 |url-status=live }} As of 2019, Musk indicated that there would be a solar roof option which would add {{convert|15|mi}} of range per day.{{cite web|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=2019-11-22|title=Tesla Cybertruck will have solar roof option to add 15 miles of range per day|url=https://electrek.co/2019/11/22/tesla-cybertruck-solar-roof-option-add-range/|access-date=2020-07-13|website=Electrek|language=en-US}} Beginning in November 2019, Tesla has accepted Cybertruck pre-orders with a US$100 deposit, and offered a US$10,000 '[[Tesla Autopilot#Full self-driving capability|full self-driving]]' option.{{cite web|url=https://www.tesla.com/cybertruck/design|title=Design Your Cybertruck|website=www.tesla.com|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122061840/https://www.tesla.com/cybertruck/design|archive-date=22 November 2019|access-date=2019-11-24}}{{update after|2021|2|8}} Tesla stated in 2019 that they expected the EPA range of the Cybertruck to range from {{convert|250-500|miles|km|round=50|abbr=out}}, depending on configuration selections.{{cite web|last=Langness|first=Travis|date=2020-08-06|title=2021 Tesla Cybertruck Prices, Reviews, and Pictures|url=https://www.edmunds.com/tesla/cybertruck/|access-date=2020-09-27|website=Edmunds|language=en-us}} === Interior === The interior of the prototype unveiled on 21 November 2019 included a 17-inch center display, seating for 6 using two bench seats with the front middle seat being a fold-down center arm rest, a digital rear-view camera based mirror, a race car style [[Yoke (aeronautics)|steering yoke]], and a [[dashboard]] with a surface resembling marble.{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTw1eOpjHi4 |title=Riding in a Tesla Cybertruck is Unlike Any Other Tesla |first=Ben |last=Sullins |access-date=2019-11-26 |via=YouTube |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191128024045/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTw1eOpjHi4 |archive-date=28 November 2019 |url-status=live }} The rear middle seat folds down to allow loading long cargo extending into the cab from the vault (enclosed lockable bed).{{cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/top-10-tesla-cybertruck-hidden-features-you-may-have-missed/|title=Top 10 Tesla Cybertruck hidden features you may have missed|last=Alvarez|first=Simon|date=2019-11-26|website=TESLARATI|language=en-US|access-date=2019-11-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191129150850/https://www.teslarati.com/top-10-tesla-cybertruck-hidden-features-you-may-have-missed/|archive-date=29 November 2019|url-status=live}} The "marble look" dashboard of the unveil prototype vehicle was a [[Paper composite panels|paper composite]] material made from "paper, wood-based fibers, natural wood pigments and non-petroleum based resins."{{cite news |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-marble-dashboard-paper-material/ |title=Tesla Cybertruck's 'marble' dashboard is actually made from paper and it's genius |work=Teslarati |date=25 November 2019 |access-date=26 November 2019 |first=Joey |last=Klender |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191224051245/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-marble-dashboard-paper-material/ |archive-date=24 December 2019 |url-status=live }} === Vault (bed) === [[File:Tesla Cybertruck unveiling.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Rear view]] The bed of the truck is planned to be a standard-bed size, {{convert|6.5|ft}} long, similar to a conventional pickup truck bed. It has sloped side walls, similar to a first-generation [[Honda Ridgeline]], and a planned integral motorized [[roller shutter]] style [[tonneau]] cover to improve the aerodynamics of the vehicle. Because of the additional security this provides, Tesla terms this {{convert|100|ft3|adj=on}} enclosed space "the vault". It includes [[Solid-state lighting|LED light strips]] along each side, an additional under-floor storage space behind the rear wheels, 120 and 240 [[Volt|V]] [[Alternating current|AC]] outlets, and a [[compressed air]] outlet for [[pneumatic tools]].{{cite web |url=https://www.teslarati.com/top-10-tesla-cybertruck-hidden-features-you-may-have-missed/ |title=Top 10 Tesla Cybertruck hidden features you may have missed |last=Alvarez |first=Simon |date=26 November 2019 |website=Teslarati |language=en-US |access-date=2019-11-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191129150850/https://www.teslarati.com/top-10-tesla-cybertruck-hidden-features-you-may-have-missed/ |archive-date=29 November 2019 |url-status=live }} While one article claims that there is a pass-through to the cabin for long cargo,{{r|Alvarez}} the displayed prototype lacks any corresponding opening in the front of the bed.{{cite web |title=ALL CyberTruck discussion |author=Mongo |date=26 November 2019 |website=Tesla Motors Club |type=forum posting |access-date=2019-11-27 |url=https://teslamotorsclub.com/tmc/posts/4241098/ |quote=the bed has no pass through that I see}} The cabin's climate control was expected to be available in the vault for uses such as camping.{{cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-camping-mode-hvac-truck-bed/|title=Tesla Cybertruck owners will be able to "camp" in the truck bed, says Elon Musk|last=Randell Suba|date=2019-12-18|website=TESLARATI|language=en-US|access-date=2019-12-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191218152125/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-cybertruck-camping-mode-hvac-truck-bed/|archive-date=18 December 2019|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/12/18/tesla-cybertruck-bed-access-2nd-row-great-camping-machine/|title=Tesla Cybertruck's bed accessible from 2nd row, making a great camping machine|last=Dow|first=Jameson|date=2019-12-18|website=Electrek|language=en-US|access-date=2019-12-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191218152126/https://electrek.co/2019/12/18/tesla-cybertruck-bed-access-2nd-row-great-camping-machine/|archive-date=18 December 2019|url-status=live}} == Design == [[File:Tesla ASM Lineup of Vehicles.jpg|thumb|A lineup of preproduction Tesla vehicles, including the Cybertruck, on display in September 2020]] According to Musk, the design of the Cybertruck was inspired by ''[[Blade Runner]]'' and the [[Lotus Esprit]] driven by James Bond in ''[[The Spy Who Loved Me (film)|The Spy Who Loved Me]]'', which [[Wet Nellie|doubled as a submarine]]. The Cybertruck uses [[stressed skin]] construction (termed an "[[exoskeleton]]" by Tesla){{cite news |title=Musk says it's really tough, not fake tough |first=Ciprian |last=Florea |date=23 November 2019 |journal=TopSpeed |url=https://www.topspeed.com/cars/car-news/tesla-cybertruck-exoskeleton-and-design-explained-ar187129.html |quote=Tesla designed an exoskeleton, a fancier word for unibody layout}}{{cite web |title=What is Cybertruck Exoskeleton? |author=Ollie |website=Teslas Motors Club |type=forum post |date=24 November 2019 |url=https://teslamotorsclub.com/tmc/threads/what-is-cybertruck-exoskeleton.174936/ |quote=All modern cars except most pickup trucks have a frameless exoskeleton, AKA monocoque or unibody.}} like most modern aircraft, rather than the [[body-on-frame]] construction which is typical of trucks,{{cite news |title=Tesla: Cybertruck uses stainless-steel 'exoskeleton' rather than traditional body-on-frame |first=John |last=Huetter |date=22 November 2019 |journal=Repairer Driven News |url=https://www.repairerdrivennews.com/2019/11/22/tesla-cybertruck-uses-stainless-steel-exoskeleton-rather-than-traditional-body-on-frame/}} as a standard [[vehicle frame]] would conflict with the under-floor battery pack.{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Burns |title=Here's why the Tesla Cybertruck has its crazy look |quote=Saved-You-A-Click: Because it's a unibody truck |date=22 November 2019 |url=https://techcrunch.com/2019/11/22/heres-why-the-tesla-cybertruck-has-its-crazy-look/ |work=[[TechCrunch]] |access-date=25 November 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191126015127/https://techcrunch.com/2019/11/22/heres-why-the-tesla-cybertruck-has-its-crazy-look/ |archive-date=26 November 2019 |url-status=live }} It uses unusually thick {{cvt|3|mm|in|frac=8}} [[Austenitic chromium-nickel steel|30x-series]] [[Cold-formed steel|cold-rolled]] [[stainless steel]] body panels, which cannot be [[Stamping (metalworking)|stamped]] like conventional automobile parts. The panels can only be bent along straight lines, resulting in a very distinctive [[facet]]ed design which has been called "[[low-poly]]" or likened to [[origami]].{{cite magazine |last=Ireson |first=Nelson |title=Is the Tesla Cybertruck *Really* Bulletproof? |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-bulletproof-stainless-steel-body/ |magazine=[[Motor Trend]] |quote='If fully hardened, 3mm of 301 stainless is more than adequate to stop any 9mm Luger round I can think of...' said Iain Harrison, editor-in-chief of Recoil as well as a competitive shooter and former British Army captain. ... Elon Musk says the laminated windshield, which appears to be completely flat, will stop a 9mm round, as well. We tested its strength by dropping weighed metal spheres from various heights. It didn't break. |date=2019-11-22 |access-date=2019-11-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122155828/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-bulletproof-stainless-steel-body/ |archive-date=22 November 2019 |url-status=live }} This material is the same material [[SpaceX]] (also owned by Musk) uses on their [[SpaceX Starship|Starship]] Rocket, because it distributes stress more evenly and allows for more interior volume.{{cite web|url=https://www.automoblog.net/2019/11/22/tesla-cybertruck-overview/|title=Tesla Cybertruck: The Future of Trucks? We're Not Sure But We Like It|last=Reyes|first=Alvin|date=2019-11-22|website=Automoblog|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191222021127/https://www.automoblog.net/2019/11/22/tesla-cybertruck-overview/|archive-date=22 December 2019|access-date=2019-11-27}} Earlier design concepts for Cybertruck had included using [[titanium]] for the outer panels, but this was later switched to stainless steel for additional strength,{{cite tweet|first=Elon|last=Musk|author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|number=1198702136231526401|date=2019-11-24|access-date=2019-11-30|title=Starship steel decision came first. We were going to use titanium skins for Cybertruck, but cold-rolled 30X stainless is much stronger.}} using an alloy that was developed in-house by Tesla.{{cite tweet|first=Elon|last=Musk|author-link=Elon Musk|user=elonmusk|number=1198704127439560705|date=2019-11-24|access-date=2020-04-20|title=We're creating this alloy at Tesla. Not a problem to create a lot of it, but we'll need to come up with new body manufacturing methods, as it can't be made using standard methods.}} === Specifications === The [[powertrain]] for the dual motor AWD version is similar to the 2019 and newer "Raven" Tesla [[Tesla Model S|Model S]] and [[Tesla Model X|Model X]], all of which have an inductive rear motor and the [[Tesla Model 3|Model 3]]'s permanent-magnet motor in front.{{cite magazine |last1=Reynolds |first1=Kim |title=How Tesla's Cybertruck Turns Auto Manufacturing and Engineering Upside-Down |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-engineering-manufacturing |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191122170053/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cybertruck-electric-pickup-engineering-manufacturing |archive-date=2019-11-22 |url-status=live|magazine=[[Motor Trend]] |date=2019-11-22 |quote=The plusses for a folded stainless steel, origami truck are compelling: no paint shop and no expensive tooling. No Godzilla-scale stamping machines stomping it with multiple strikes. groove the steel where it's supposed to fold (avoiding cracks) and bend it on simple, cheap machines}} Other versions are single-motor rear-wheel drive, or tri-motor with one front and two rear motors. Similar to other Tesla models, the Cybertruck can be pre-ordered with Full Self-Driving software upgrade, adding an additional US$10,000 to the price of the configuration.{{cite web |url=https://www.tesla.com/cybertruck/design |title=Design Your Cybertruck |date=2019-11-22 |website=Tesla website |access-date=2021-09-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191122061840/https://www.tesla.com/cybertruck/design |archive-date=22 November 2019 |url-status=dead}}{{cite web|last=Szymkowski|first=Sean|title=Tesla Full Self-Driving feature now costs $10,000|url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-full-self-driving-beta-elon-musk-price/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Roadshow|language=en}}{{Update inline|reason=Software upgrade cannot be added now.|date=October 2021}} {| class="wikitable" |+Tesla Cybertruck (initial) model specifications !Model !Range (EPA est.) !{{cvt|0–60|mph|km/h|0}} !Top speed !Payload !Towing capacity !Price ([[USD]]) !Availability |- |Single Motor RWD |{{Convert|400|km|mi|abbr=on}} |< 6.5 seconds |{{cvt|110|mph|round=5|order=flip}} |{{cvt|3,500|lb|kg|round=50|order=flip}} |{{cvt|7500|lb|t|round=|abbr=on|order=flip}} |TBA ($39,900) |TBA |- |Dual Motor AWD |{{Convert|480|km|mi|abbr=on}} |< 4.5 seconds |{{cvt|120|mph|round=5|order=flip}} |{{cvt|3,500|lb|kg|round=50|order=flip}} |{{cvt|10000|lb|t|abbr=on|order=flip}} |TBA ($49,900) |TBA |- |Tri Motor AWD |{{Convert|800|km|mi|abbr=on}} |< 2.9 seconds |{{cvt|130|mph|round=5|order=flip}} |{{cvt|3,500|lb|kg|round=50|order=flip}} |{{cvt|14000|lb|t|abbr=on|order=flip}} |TBA ($69,900) |TBA |- |Quad Motor AWD |TBA |TBA |TBA |TBA |TBA |TBA |TBA |} All models will have {{convert|100|ft3|m3|order=|abbr=}} of storage space, and a {{convert|6.5|ft|m|order=|adj=mid|-long|abbr=}} cargo area. As an off-road vehicle, up to {{convert|16|in|cm|round=10|order=|abbr=}} of ground clearance is provided, with a 35 degree [[Approach and departure angles|approach angle]], and 28 degree [[Approach and departure angles|departure angle]]. In October 2021, Tesla removed the Cybertruck's pricing and specifications from its website without explanation while still accepting deposits.{{cite magazine |last=Blanco |first=Sebastian |date=16 October 2021 |title=Tesla Removes Cybertruck Specs from Website, Still Taking Deposits |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a37979446/tesla-cybertruck-specs-removed/ |magazine=Car and Driver |publisher=Hearst Autos |access-date=16 October 2021}} At the 2022 Annual Shareholders meeting, Elon Musk stated that final specifications and pricing will be materially different from those unveiled on the [[concept car|concept vehicle]] in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=49e7LrxS3FQ&t=5930s |title=Tesla, Inc. 2022 Annual Meeting of Stockholders |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2022-08-05}} == Production == {{As of|November 2019}}, Tesla Cybertruck production was scheduled to start in late 2021 and expand to offer more configurations in 2022.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.wired.com/story/electric-tesla-pickup-truck-announcement-specs-cost-photos/ |title=Tesla Cybertruck: Elon Musk's Pickup Truck Has Arrived|magazine=Wired|access-date=2019-11-23|language=en|issn=1059-1028|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191123014603/https://www.wired.com/story/electric-tesla-pickup-truck-announcement-specs-cost-photos/ |archive-date=23 November 2019|url-status=live}} By 22 July 2020, Tesla had chosen [[Austin, Texas]], ([[Giga Texas|Gigafactory Texas]]) for the production of the Cybertruck, [[Tesla Model Y|Model Y]], and [[Tesla Semi|Semi]].{{cite web|last=Szymkowski|first=Sean|title=Tesla chooses Austin for Cybertruck and Semi production, as well as production for East Coast bound Model Y.|url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-gigafactory-austin-tulsa-cybertruck-semi/|access-date=2020-07-22|website=Roadshow|language=en}} The factory will reportedly be open to the public and will include a boardwalk near the [[Colorado River (Texas)]], hiking trails, and biking trails.{{cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/7/22/21334860/tesla-cybertruck-factory-austin-texas-location-model-y|title=Tesla will build Cybertruck factory in Austin, Texas|author=Sean O'Kane|publisher=The Verge|access-date=21 August 2020}} By March 2021 a [[Giga Press]] die casting machine capable of {{convert|8000|tf|kN lbf|sigfig=1|adj=on}} had been ordered for production of the Cybertruck rear chassis casting.{{cite interview|first=Elon|last=Musk|authorlink=Elon Musk|date=2021-01-28|access-date=2021-01-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Xs-EmTnU7w|title=Tesla Q4 2020 Earnings Call|via=YouTube}}{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o2Mi84wCRg8|date=2021-03-18|accessdate=2021-03-19|publisher=Idra Group Idra|title=Giga Press|type=offset 00:31|first=Riccardo|last=Ferrario|quote=Today, on 16 March 2021, [Idra] have been able to secure the first order for an 8,000-tonne [force] die-casting machine ... placed by a leading global manufacturer for new energy vehicles ... toggles-closing, ... together with ... regenerative injection system.|via=Youtube|department=Flash News}} On August 9, 2021, the production of the Cybertruck was delayed to 2022 according to Tesla's website.{{cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a37258128/tesla-cybertruck-production-delayed/|title = Tesla Cybertruck is Delayed, and We're Not Surprised|date = 9 August 2021}} In January 2022, the production was further delayed into early 2023 and then again to end of 2023, two years after the initial production target date. {{cite web|title=Exclusive: Tesla's Cybertruck to start mass production at end of 2023|url=https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/exclusive-tesla-plans-mass-production-start-cybertruck-end-2023-sources-2022-11-01/|access-date=2022-12-10|website=Reuters|language=en}}{{cite web|title=Tesla, Inc. Q2 2022 Financial Results and Q&A Webcast|url=https://ir.tesla.com/webcast-2022-07-20|access-date=2022-08-23|website=Tesla|language=en-US}} === Market potential === In the United States, the [[total addressable market]] for full-sized pickup trucks is over two million vehicles per year.{{cite magazine|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2019/11/20/elon-musk-cybertruck-will-thrill--tesla-fans-but-its-pickup-market-potential-is-a-puzzler/ |first=Alan|last=Ohnsman|date=2019-11-20|access-date=2019-11-22|magazine=[[Forbes]]|title=Elon Musk's 'Cybertruck' Will Thrill Tesla Fans, But Its Pickup Market Potential Is A Puzzler|quote=U.S. sales of full-size pickups, the world's primary market for such vehicles, surpasses 2 million units annually, and volume leaders Ford, GM and FiatChrysler's Ram battle to retain buyer loyalty and bragging rights in a space where median prices approach $50,000.|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191122113857/https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2019/11/20/elon-musk-cybertruck-will-thrill--tesla-fans-but-its-pickup-market-potential-is-a-puzzler/ |archive-date=22 November 2019|url-status=live}} It has been argued that the Cybertruck will be able to take advantage of the Tesla Network of shared vehicles{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/04/05/tesla-network-details-april-22/ |title=More details on "Tesla Network" autonomous rideshare service coming in April 22 webcast|first=Jameson|last=Dow |date=2019-05-05|work=Electrek |access-date=2019-11-25|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190529030124/https://electrek.co/2019/04/05/tesla-network-details-april-22/ |archive-date=29 May 2019|url-status=live}} to generate an income stream,{{cite web|url=http://www.economicswebinstitute.org/essays/tesla-pickup.htm |title=Tesla Cybertruck: your next income stream?|first=Valentino|last=Piana |access-date=2019-11-25|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191207172551/http://www.economicswebinstitute.org/essays/tesla-pickup.htm |archive-date=7 December 2019|url-status=live}} if the latter were to become available in the United States{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2019/04/22/tesla-plans-to-launch-a-robotaxi-network-in-2020/ |title=Tesla plans to launch a robotaxi network in 2020|date=2019-04-22|work=Techcrunch |first=Kirsten|last=Korosec |access-date=2019-11-25|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20191106072639/https://techcrunch.com/2019/04/22/tesla-plans-to-launch-a-robotaxi-network-in-2020/ |archive-date=6 November 2019|url-status=live}} and worldwide. ==Safety concerns== The Cybertruck's design has received criticism from automotive safety groups, including the [[Australasian New Car Assessment Program]] and the [[Euro NCAP]], for not conforming to standards for pedestrian and cyclist safety. In its December 2019 form, the truck would likely not be [[Street-legal vehicle|street-legal]] in either [[Australia]] or the [[European Union]].{{cite news |last=Reid |first=Carlton|title=Tesla Cybertruck Not Street-Legal In EU |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/carltonreid/2019/12/16/tesla-cybertruck-not-street-legal-in-eu/ |date=2019-12-16 |access-date=2021-06-08 |website=Forbes |location=US}} Particular concerns highlighted by these two bodies include the high stiffness of the "exoskeleton" exterior resulting in a lack of [[crumple zone]]s, as well as the tall, flat front of the truck, which could increase the severity of leg injuries.{{Cite news|last=Hagon|first=Toby|date=26 November 2019|title=New Tesla Cybertruck could put other road users at risk|work=[[News.com.au]] |location=Australia |url=https://www.news.com.au/technology/motoring/motoring-news/new-tesla-cybertruck-could-put-other-road-users-at-risk/news-story/da648cad43ef731ae5dbb45632a6ed41|access-date=7 June 2021}} == See also == * [[Chevrolet Silverado EV]] * [[Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup|Ford F-150 Lightning]] * [[Rivian R1T]] * [[GMC Hummer EV]] * [[Lordstown Endurance]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == *From Elon Musk's June 2018 "What would you love to see in a Tesla pickup truck?" Driver's seat will be big enough to fit André the giant (love that guy).|link=no}} ** {{cite tweet|number=1011835761182666752 |first=Elon|last=Musk |user=elonmusk|author-link=Elon Musk|date=2018-06-27|title=400 to 500 mile option definitely.
